issues.description: Class name inconsistency: the UML and task text in the problem statement refer to the park class as 'ExcellencePark', while the template and solution repositories use the class/file name 'ExcellenceLand' (and some task/check names reference 'ExcellentLand'). This mismatch between the name used in the specification and the actual class in the starter/solution code will confuse students about which class to declare/implement and which name the tests expect.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the park class name consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) rename the class in template/solution to 'ExcellencePark' (and the file to ExcellencePark.java) and update any test/check names accordingly, or (B) update the UML and problem text/tasks to refer to 'ExcellenceLand' (and use the same 'ExcellentLand' check names consistently). Ensure the task descriptions and any verification function names match the chosen class name.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares the park class as 'ExcellencePark' while both the template and the reference solution use the class/file name 'ExcellenceLand'. The exercise text also refers to the park as "Excellence Land". This mismatch between the UML/task name (ExcellencePark) and the actual template/solution class (ExcellenceLand) can confuse students: task descriptions and tests refer to ExcellencePark but the provided starter code and solution expect/contain ExcellenceLand, making it unclear which class name students should implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the park class name consistent across all artifacts. Preferred fix: rename the UML class and all task references from 'ExcellencePark' to 'ExcellenceLand' (to match the textual description "Excellence Land" and the template/solution). Alternatively, rename the template and solution class/file to 'ExcellencePark' and update the textual description to match. Ensure tasks, UML, template filenames, and tests all use the same identifier.
